skos:Concept.skos:definition: {"id": "71756205-91f2-4c0d-83a3-5f217ccdcd09", "value": "One intermediate stabilisation pathway in which radiative forcing is limited at approximately 4.5 W m\u20132 in 2100 (the corresponding Extended Concentration Pathway, or ECP, has constant concentrations after 2150)."}

{"id": "dac95715-a08f-4c29-b87f-5efc76cfb5bd", "value": "Scenarios that include time series of emissions and concentrations of the full suite of greenhouse gases (GHGs) and aerosols and chemically active gases, as well as land use/land cover (Moss et al.,2008; van Vuuren et al., 2011). The word representative signifies that each RCP provides only one of many possible scenarios that would lead to the specific radiative forcing characteristics. The term pathway emphasises that not only the long-term concentration levels are of interest, but also the trajectory taken over time to reach that outcome (Moss et al., 2010; van Vuuren et al., 2011)."}

{"id": "7cdfcd57-a676-4c1a-8dca-dad8bc0668e1", "value": "One high pathway which leads to >8.5 W m\u20132 in 2100 (the corresponding Extended Concentration Pathway, or ECP, has constant emissions after 2100 until 2150 and constant concentrations after 2250)."}

{"id": "a891725c-cf82-4975-8014-de328b011d38", "value": "One pathway where radiative forcing peaks at approximately 3 W m\u20132 and then declines to be limited at 2.6 W m\u20132 in 2100 (the corresponding Extended Concentration Pathway, or ECP, has constant emissions after 2100)\u201d"}

{"id": "fff47569-86e7-466a-87d2-3f6f7749d601", "value": "One intermediate stabilisation pathway in which radiative forcing is limited at approximately 6.0 W m\u20132 in 2100 (the corresponding Extended Concentration Pathway, or ECP, has constant concentrations after 2150)."}

{"id": "b2f4c270-c732-4e87-8d7b-c9b0f7dc6f1f", "value": "Shared Socio-economic Pathways (SSPs) have been developed to complement the Representative Concentration Pathways (RCPs). By design, the RCP emission and concentration pathways were stripped of their association with a certain socio-economic development. Different levels of emissions and climate change along the dimension of the RCPs can hence be explored against the backdrop of different socio-economic development pathways (SSPs) on the other dimension in a matrix. This integrative SSP-RCP framework is now widely used in the climate impact and policy analysis literature, where climate projections obtained under the RCP scenarios are analysed against the backdrop of various SSPs. As several emissions updates were due, a new set of emissions scenarios was developed in conjunction with the SSPs. Hence, the abbreviation SSP is now used for two things: On the one hand SSP1, SSP2, \u2026, SSP5 are used to denote the five socio-economic scenario families. On the other hand, the abbreviations SSP1-1.9, SSP1-2.6, \u2026, SSP5-8.5 are used to denote the newly developed emissions scenarios that are the result of an SSP implementation within an integrated assessment model. Those SSP scenarios are bare of climate policy assumption, but in combination with so-called shared policy assumptions (SPAs), various approximate radiative forcing levels of 1.9, 2.6, \u2026, or 8.5 W m\u20132 are reached by the end of the century, respectively."}
